fields.description:
h1. Steps to reproduce (with the UI)

# Login to a Bamboo instance (Cloud or Server, verified with Server 5.12.0-m427)
# Open a build plan page
# Open the Chrome Web Tools to see the AJAX requests
# In another tab in the same browser, log out from Bamboo
# Back in the first tab, the requests to {{/ajax/planStatusHistoryNeighbouringSummaries.action}}, which used to return 200 when the user was logged in, now return 302 redirections to the login page.

h1. Steps to reproduce (command line)

{code}
$ export MY_BAMBOO_URL=https://your-bamboo
$ curl -X GET -I "$MY_BAMBOO_URL/ajax/planStatusHistoryNeighbouringSummaries.action"
HTTP/1.1 302 Found
Cache-Control: max-age=0
Content-Language: en-US
Date: Tue, 10 May 2016 05:05:48 GMT
Expires: Tue, 10 May 2016 05:05:48 GMT
Location: /userlogin!default.action;jsessionid=EDITED?os_destination=%2Fajax%2FplanStatusHistoryNeighbouringSummaries.action
Server: Apache-Coyote/1.1
Set-Cookie: JSESSIONID=EDITED; Path=/; Secure; HttpOnly
Content-Length: 0
Connection: keep-alive
{code}
fields.summary: Unauthenticated /ajax requests should return 401, not a 302 redirection to the login page

fields.description: Currently their is no way to automate creation of Linked repositories, it would be great if we had a REST endpoint to automate this task.
fields.summary: Add a REST endpoint to add/update "Linked Repositories"

fields.description:
On the plan summary page, there is a drop-down selector with a branch icon and a list of branches.  At the bottom of the list is a link "View all branches".  I request to change the text to "View all branch plans" with the following justification:

I had an old PR whose branch plan had expired.  I wanted to re-enable or re-create the branch plan.  Not being familiar with how branch plan expiry works, I wasn't sure exactly how to do this, but I assumed it should be obvious enough how to do this.

I got tripped up, however, by the "View all branches" link.  Assuming based on the name of the link that this would let me see all branches, and from there I could re-enable or re-create the branch plan, I was confused when the resulting page didn't have my branch listed.  I was going to file a bug report saying that somehow my branch had been lost from Bamboo, but first I got a more experienced Bamboo user to check my work.  At that point I realized that the "View all branches" link actually takes you to a list of branch *plans*, and then of course it made sense that my expired branch plan was not listed.

It's true that the linked page does have the text "Plan branches" in bold near the top, but it also has a tab title of just "Branches" and a URL ending in "..../branches".  More consistent naming would help with discovery for other novice users like me.

Also consider renaming the "Branches" tab to "Branch Plans", and possibly include text or a link to aid in discovery of the "Actions => Configure Plan => Branches => Create plan branch" button.

Thanks for considering!
fields.summary: Feature request: "View all branches" => "View all branch plans"

fields.description:
h4. Summary
Java 8 update 20 has introduced an additional flag for the G1 garbage collector that enables string deduplication to lower the memory footprint of the JVM. The functionality can be enabled by adding the {{-XX:+UseStringDeduplication}} JVM flag.

More information about this parameter can be found in the following links:
- [https://blogs.oracle.com/java-platform-group/entry/g1_from_garbage_collector_to]
- [http://java-performance.info/java-string-deduplication/]
- [https://blog.codecentric.de/en/2014/08/string-deduplication-new-feature-java-8-update-20-2/]

h4. Suggestion
Evaluate adding this parameter by default, as it is said not to cause significant performance overhead, however it can save additional heap memory, asynchronously to GC cycles.
fields.summary: Enable string deduplication by default

fields.description: It would be great if there is a current date variable to be used in deployment release versioning.
fields.summary: Add current date variable to deployment release versioning

fields.description:
Selecting the source plan is pretty broken in Atlassian Bamboo version 5.12.0-m427 build 51209 - 04 May 16.

Tip: when you land in the view and select and item, it works straight away, but if you type something on the source plan input the component gets into an inconsistent state where mouse clicks are not getting handled properly.

Please have a look at the video.

You should be able to reproduce it easily in https://collaboration-bamboo.internal.atlassian.com/build/admin/edit/editBuildTasks.action?buildKey=FIL-HCME-DTA. Otherwise you can talk to me.
fields.summary: Broken selection on "Artifact download configuration source plan"

fields.description:
h3. Problem:
The official page *Integrating Bamboo with LDAP* has a link pointing to a private page.
This is the page link: https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/integrating-bamboo-with-ldap-289277210.html
The *Mapping Active Directory* can be found at *Step 4 — Map LDAP Data Tree* section.
This is the page pointed for that link: https://confluence.atlassian.com/dev/confluence-ldap-documentation-index/mapping-active-directory-to-confluence

h3. Suggested resolution
Fix the link, so it points to a public page with updated content.
fields.summary: Please fix the "Mapping Active Directory" link at "Integrating Bamboo with LDAP" page

Some API has been prematurely removed in 5.11

fields.description: This bug https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SSHD-646 affects Bamboo SSH proxy which is used by all ssh-based repository access methods. This will eventually lead to OOME.
fields.summary: Upgrade apache-sshd to fix SSHD-646

fields.description:
The health check plugin notes a few possible issues with MySQL instances, and includes a "How can I resolve this?" link to a KB article, however the KB article does not actually show how to fix the issue, it just explains the message (the health check plugin already shows an explanation)

Examples:
https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Bamboo+MySQL+InnoDB+Log+File+Size
https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Bamboo+MySQL+Max+Allowed+Packets
https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Bamboo+MySQL+Character+Set
https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Bamboo+MySQL+Collation


Ideally we should include the steps to resolve the issue, e.g. the changes to make in the MySQL conf file or queries to be run against their instance, as the hyperlink text in the health check plugin suggest that the linked article should contain a solution
fields.summary: Health Check plugin - "How can I resolve this?" docs don't explain how to resolve

fields.description:
When the health check plugin reports a value not recommended for the * max_allowed_packet* setting for MySQL, it reports the variable name incorrectly as *max_allowed_packets*

This is also referenced in the kb article https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Bamboo+MySQL+Max+Allowed+Packets

Can this be amended to show the correct variable name of *max_allowed_packet*
fields.summary: Health Check plugin - "max_allowed_packets" for MySQL should be "max_allowed_packet"

fields.description:
h3. Summary

It is not possible to secure the remote agents to connect to the Bamboo Server (using SSL) through the automatic keystore management feature.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Download & Install Bamboo 5.11.x.
 # Follow the [Securing your remote agents|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Securing+your+remote+agents] documentation to use the *automatic keystore management* feature.
 # Install the remote agent.

h3. Expected Results

The automatic keystore management feature handles the SSL configuration and creates the following files:
 # The remote agent keystore at {{BAMBOO_AGENT_HOME/xml-data/configuration/jmsclient.ks}}.
 # The remote agent truststore at {{BAMBOO_AGENT_HOME/xml-data/configuration/jmsclient.ts}}.
 # The Bamboo server keystore at {{BAMBOO_HOME/xml-data/configuration/broker.ks}}.

The remote agent is able to connect to the Bamboo server using SSL.
h3. Actual Results

The remote agent truststore at {{BAMBOO_AGENT_HOME/xml-data/configuration/jmsclient.ts}} is *not* created and the installation fails with the following error message:

h3. Workarounds
h4. Workaround A: Upgrade + remote agents already connected via SSL

Use this workaround if your goal is to upgrade to an affected version (e.g. 5.10.3 to 5.12.2.1) and you already have a remote agent connected to the Bamboo server using SSL.
 # Install the remote agent but note that this bug will prevent it from connecting. Refer to the [Bamboo remote agent installation guide|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Bamboo+remote+agent+installation+guide] for details.
 # Stop the remote agent.
 # Copy the keys (.ks & .ts) from a *working* remote agent to the newly installed agent. You'll find the keys here:
 ** {{BAMBOO_AGENT_HOME/xml-data/configuration/jmsclient.ks}}
 ** {{BAMBOO_AGENT_HOME/xml-data/configuration/jmsclient.ts}}
 # Start the remote agent.

h4. Workaround B: Add secure remote agents for the first time

Use this workaround if you are already running the affected version and for the first time you need to set up a secure remote agent.
 # Follow the instructions to create certificates manually. Refer to instructions on [How to secure your remote agent (Bamboo Server)|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamkb/how-to-secure-your-remote-agent-bamboo-server-757465762.html] for details.
 # Add the newly created certificates to the Java truststore ({{cacerts}} is the default truststore). For example, this is how to import the manually created certificate "bamboo.secure.server.crt" into the Java truststore using Linux:
{code:java}
sudo keytool -import -trustcacerts -file /opt/atlassian/home/atlassian-bamboo-5.12.2.1/xml-data/configuration/bamboo.secure.server.crt -alias "bamboo.secure.server" -keystore $JAVA_HOME/jre/lib/security/cacerts
{code}

 # Configure both the Bamboo server and the agent(s) to not use the automatic certificates but the manually created ones instead by passing in the {{-Dbamboo.manage.jms.ssl=false}} JVM parameter on startup:
 ** Bamboo server
{code:java|title=<bamboo-install>/bin/setenv.sh}

After link creation, Bamboo is unable to list the Bitbucket server link in the application link config screen.

* Bamboo 5.9.7

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create application link from Bamboo to Bitbucket

The Bitbucket server link should be listed in the config screen

fields.description:
This affects Bamboo on Atlassian Cloud.

When a Linked Repository (LR) is created, by default only the user who created it has permissions to manage it. Other administrators are unable to manage the LR or even see who created it.

By default, site-admins or bamboo-administrators should have permission to manage any LR in their account.
fields.summary: Site or Bamboo Admins should be able to manage all Linked Repositories

fields.description:
Hi, I just went through an upgrade of a code analysis tool we used that illustrated a couple things that would be nice to have for server capability set up.  

# Our jobs run several tasks that are associated with the tool, these are various command line programs.  In upgrading from say version 1.0.0 to 2.0.0 I had to go to each of the capability definitions and update the path.  It would be nice if I could define 'tool_root_path=/tool/1.0.0' and reference ${tool_root_path} in the capability definition

# The other thing that happened in this upgrade was a change/deprecation in one of the command line tools.  Instead of being say '.../analyze_java' it became '..../analyze --java'  currently I can't seem to define a capability with a default argument.  So in this case I had to change it to just '../analyze' then update _all_ the tasks that used the capability to add the new argument.
fields.summary: Add support for user variables and default arguments for server capabilities

fields.description:
We currently use Atlassian Bamboo Server v5.10.1.1 build 51018 and our NCover code coverage statistic is not being displayed in the build results view.

If you check the "NCover output will be produced" checkbox under the "Miscellaneous" tab of the job configuration, the "NCover" tab itself will be visible in the build/job result and the "NCOVER_ASSEMBLIES", "NCOVER_CLASSES", ... keys are also being generated during the build and visible under the "Metadata" tab.
Only the displaying of the results doesn't work.

So I poked around in the bamboo-dotnet-plugin source code and found the following line in "main/resources/com/atlassian/bamboo/plugin/dotnet/ncover/viewNCoverResult.ftl" (line 10):

{code:java}
[#assign customDataMap=buildResults.buildResultsSummary.customBuildData /]
{code}

This results in a "[runtime] Expression buildResults.buildResultsSummary is undefined on line 10, column 28 in com/atlassian/bamboo/plugin/dotnet/ncover/viewNCoverResult.ftl" exception whenever you try to view the NCover build results.

After poking around in some other plugins and how those build results work, I changed this line to:

{code:java}
[#assign customDataMap=buildResultsSummary.customBuildData /]
{code}

Now the NCover result is displayed correctly.

Can you please take a look and check whether this will fix this issue for good?

Thanks
Cheers, Chris
fields.summary: DotNet Plugin: tab with NCover results not working

fields.description:
By default:
* Caching is enabled in the LDAP [documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/integrating-bamboo-with-ldap-289277210.html]
* LDAP specific cache configuration is commented out in <Bamboo installation directory>/atlassian-bamboo/WEB-INF/classes/ehcache.xml
* _defaultCache_ property "eternal" set to "true" which means that elements have no timeout

As an effect of this configuration, the cache is only rotated once it reaches the maximum elements in memory. 

h5. Problem Statement
One of the possible issues that is most commonly faced in this scenario is that Bamboo does not update it's LDAP cache or information when LDAP is updated (example: user removed or password change) until a restart.

h5. Workaround
To workaround this issue, users should configure LDAP specific caching as instructed in the below documentation:
https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/configuring-the-caching-of-your-ldap-repository-289277216.html

h5. Suggestion
Use non-eternal caching for LDAP by default so that elements have a timeout and refreshed accordingly.
fields.summary: Use non eternal caching for LDAP by default

fields.description:
h3. Summary
The recently introduced Admin permission for linked repositories is not automatically granted to Bamboo administrators. As such, the Bamboo Administration -> Linked Repositories page does not display all repositories when viewed by a user with Bamboo administrator privileges. 

h3. Environment
Bamboo Cloud

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create two users both with administrative access to Bamboo
# Create a linked repository using one of these users
# Attempt to view said repository when logged in as the other admin user

h3. Expected Results
Administrators are able to view all linked repositories defined in their Bamboo Cloud application and newly created repositories grant the Admin permission to Bamboo administrators by default.

h3. Actual Results
Only repositories that the admin user created will be displayed. Linked repositories created by other users are not visible.

h3.Workaround
As a Bamboo administrator, navigate directly to https://<hostname>.atlassian.net/builds/vcs/viewAllRepositories.action. From there you can manually update the permissions for each repository and grant your current Bamboo administrators group the Use and Admin permissions.
fields.summary: Bamboo Administrators Not Granted Admin Permission on Linked Repositories

fields.description:
All windows distros of 5.11.1 do not contain the tomcat executables while all prior versions do. This will stop customers on Windows from upgrading unless they manually add the files in themselves.

h5. Workaround 
# Download these binaries: 
** 32bit: [^tomcat_32_bit.zip] 
** 64bit: [^tomcat_64_bit.zip] 
# Extract them into {{Bamboo Installation Directory/bin}} 
# Try running _InstallAsService.bat_ again

fields.description:
Currently if you want this data you'll have to manually query the DB for it (which can vary from version to version of both Bamboo and the DB itself).

It would be nice if Bamboo included a report that listed all projects with drill down builds/deployments and other pertinent info (success/failure rate, last time build, owner of project, etc.). This report should be granular enough to filter/sort/group by criteria.
fields.summary: Report for all builds/plans/deployments/projects

fields.description:
Not only does Bamboo not have support for Git LFS, but the way in which Bamboo works conflicts with Git LFS in (at least) the following ways: 

1. The "Source Code Checkout" task utilizes a local cache which is not a full mirror of the remote repository, so it does not contain LFS objects. (Git LFS does not support the "file:///" protocol anyways.)
2. Branch builds with merging enabled do not work with Git LFS because they leave the raw LFS files in a modified state, which causes Git LFS to ignore them when performing a pull or checkout. 
3. The saved credentials within Bamboo are unavailable to custom scripts/commands (such as a custom Git LFS script), so they have to be manually configured and separately maintained. 

I understand that BAM-17160 already covers Git LFS support, but I wanted to ensure that the specific issues that I've encountered are addressed when Git LFS support is added.
fields.summary: Git LFS Support

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Remote agents inside the Docker images are failing to start up with an {{"Unsupported major.minor version 52.0"}} error. This usually happens when we try to run a class compiled using a higher Java version (e.g. Java 8) compiler into a lower Java version (e.g. Java 7), because higher versions usually have features that are not supported by lower versions.

It is necessary to update the Java version inside the Docker images provided by Atlassian at https://hub.docker.com/u/atlassian/.

{noformat}
atlassian/bamboo-java-agent
atlassian/bamboo-base-agent
{noformat}

They're currently running Java 7, according to our [doc|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO0510/Getting+started+with+Docker+and+Bamboo]. However remote agents 5.10.x *will not* start up with Java 6 or 7, it is necessary to have Java 8 installed, as per the [Supported Platforms|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO0510/Supported+platforms].

h3. Steps to Reproduce
Follow the [Getting started with Docker and Bamboo|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Getting+started+with+Docker+and+Bamboo] documentation to make use of the Docker images provided by Atlassian at https://hub.docker.com/u/atlassian/.

h3. Expected Results

The remote agent starts up and is ready to build.

h3. Actual Results
The remote agent fails to start up with the following error message:

{noformat}
Running [/root/bamboo-agent-home/bin/bamboo-agent.sh, console]
Agent process started, shutdown hook registered, proceeding with log pump...
Running Bamboo Agent...

Bamboo Agent Installer is shutting down, the underlying agent process has already been shut down.
{noformat}

{panel:borderStyle=solid| borderColor=#6A8EB3 |bgColor=#E7F4FA}
h3. Workaround

h5. Step 1: Customization

To customize an image, run it in a container. Name the container for easier access later. In this example we will call it *ATL*:

# {noformat}sudo docker run --name="ATL" -e HOME=/root/ -i -t atlassian/bamboo-java-agent:latest /bin/bash{noformat}
Once you run this command you'll get automatically logged in to the container.

h5. Step 2: Install additional Ubuntu packages

We have to add some packages to Ubuntu so we can install Java through the command line:

# {noformat}sudo apt-get install python-software-properties{noformat}
# {noformat}sudo apt-get update{noformat}
# {noformat}sudo apt-get install software-properties-common{noformat}

h5. Step 3: Install Java

In this example we will download Java 8 from the [Webup8|http://www.webupd8.org/2012/09/install-oracle-java-8-in-ubuntu-via-ppa.html] repository. In this step you can use any repository you want to download Java 8 from. This is only one example of repository that you can use to download Java 8 from. Use this at your own risk.

# {noformat}sudo add-apt-repository ppa:webupd8team/java{noformat}
# {noformat}sudo apt-get update{noformat}
# {noformat}sudo apt-get install oracle-java8-installer{noformat}

Now we have to set up the Java 8 environment variables:

# {noformat}sudo apt-get install oracle-java8-set-default{noformat}
# {noformat}export JAVA_HOME=path/to/jdk/install{noformat}
# {noformat}export PATH=$JAVA_HOME/bin:$PATH{noformat}

h5. Step 4: Building your own image

Here you will create a new image from the container you've installed Java 8. Without closing the terminal window you're using to access the container, open a *new* terminal window and run:
# {noformat}sudo docker commit ATL customized-bamboo-java-agent:1.0.0{noformat}

h5. Step 5: Verify your custom image

Run the following command from the terminal window to check your current docker images. You should see your customized image named {{customized-bamboo-java-agent}} in the list with TAG {{1.0.0}}.

# {noformat}docker images{noformat}

h5. Step 6: Start your customized Docker image

# {noformat}sudo docker run -e HOME=/root/ -e BAMBOO_SERVER=http://hostname:port/bamboo -i -t customized-bamboo-java-agent:1.0.0{noformat}

{panel}
fields.summary: Update the Java version inside the Atlassian Docker images

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Password masking in logs outputs a lot of asterisks if any of the password variable contain an asterisk and there is more than 1 password variable.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create 2 variables with password in it's name:
## password1 = 123
## password2 = *
# Add a script task that does any command, example {{echo "Hello"}}
# Run the plan

h3. Expected Results
In the build logs, it should show:
password1=********
password2=********

h3. Actual Results
For each password Bamboo would show 512 asterisks

h3. Extent
If you have multiple variables that contain passwords of just asterisks, the number of asterisks will increase by 8 exponent. If there is 10 variables containing just asterisks, Bamboo will create 1 billion asterisks for each password variable in the logs.


h3. Workaround

For Bamboo 5.10.3. This patched jar will prevent the cascading effect of the password masking.
# Stop Bamboo
# Backup {{<bamboo install dir>/atlassian-bamboo/WEB-INF/lib/atlassian-bamboo-api-5.10.3.jar}} to a separate directory
# Place this file in the above directory [^atlassian-bamboo-api-5.10.3.jar]
# Start Bamboo
fields.summary: Password masking in logs outputs a lot of asterisks if any of the password variable contain an asterisk

fields.description:
We have a recurring and intermittent problem where our Windows remote agents fail to delete the output of a previous build with the error 'Unable to clean source directory 'c:\buildarea' Unable to delete file: '
Subsequent rebuilds will usually succeed on the same agent.
When we've managed to catch this problem on an agent the directory will be locked by the process CcmExec.exe
Is this issue known and if so do you have any advice on how we might avoid it?

Bamboo server version 5.3 build 4101 - 09 Dec 13
fields.summary: Unable to clean source directory 'c:\buildarea' Unable to delete file:

fields.description:
Use REST call 
{{/queue/\{projectKey\}-\{buildKey\}?stage&executeAllStages&customRevision}}
to trigger a build.
This returns an HTTP 200.

When you trigger another build of this plan, while the first build is still running, it should return an HTTP 400 according to the REST API documentation (assuming you have not enabled concurrent builds).

Bamboo 5.4.2 indeed returns an HTTP 400.
Recent Bamboo versions (tested with 5.9.7 and 5.10.3) return an HTTP 500.
fields.summary: REST trigger an already running build returns HTTP 500 instead of 400

fields.description:
It should be possible to run a {{Command}} task and have bamboo ignore the result in the same way we can with a {{mvn}} task. 

I run various {{docker}} commands, to perform cleanup activities in the finally block of the build. 
{code}
docker rm $(docker ps -a -q)
{code}
When there is nothing for the script to do, i.e. result of ps -a is null, the {{docker]}} commands returns an error which is expected.  In the context of my build, this error is non-fatal.  To {{bamboo}}, it captures the command result and fails the build. 

I'd rather not have to figure out shell syntax to resolve this kind of issue and simply have bamboo ignore the error condition.
fields.summary: Ignore result of a Command

fields.description:
The current SCP and SSH tasks documentation does not show the supported SSH server for Windows
https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Using+the+SCP+task+in+Bamboo
https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Using+the+SSH+task+in+Bamboo

It would be better if there is a list of Supported SSH server for Windows since some SSH servers (that only works with SFTP) will not work well with Bamboo SCP and SSH tasks

It should state that Bamboo SSH task is sending command to the server instead of accessing the remote server interactively, eg:
{noformat}
ssh username@remotehost "ls -al"
{noformat}
fields.summary: Need to add supported SSH server for Windows to SCP and SSH tasks documentation

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Bamboo Cloud instances are not executing queued builds despite the availability of idle agents. Restarting the agents or canceling the build and re-executing occasionally clears this issue but it will eventually begin to reoccur.

This has been noted impacting both elastic and remote agents.

h3. Environment
Bamboo Cloud

h3. Steps to Reproduce
Exact method for reproduction is unknown at this time. Bamboo Cloud instances with multiple agents and high levels of build activity are experiencing this issue with high frequency.

The following error is occuring frequently in the Bamboo application logs when this behavior is present.
{noformat}
2016-04-21 18:19:22.749954500 2016-04-21 18:19:22,749 INFO [scheduler_Worker-8] [ExpiryTickerImpl] Live expiry handlers: 17
2016-04-21 18:19:29.032352500 org.apache.activemq.transport.InactivityIOException: Channel was inactive (no connection attempt made) for too (>30000) long: blockingQueue_3328772
2016-04-21 18:19:29.032365500 	at org.apache.activemq.transport.AbstractInactivityMonitor$1$1.run(AbstractInactivityMonitor.java:91)
2016-04-21 18:19:29.032366500 	at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.runWorker(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:1142)
2016-04-21 18:19:29.032366500 	at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:617)
2016-04-21 18:19:29.032372500 	at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:745)
{noformat}

h3.Workaround (partial)
Restarting the agents or canceling the build and re-executing occasionally clears this issue but it will eventually begin to reoccur.
fields.summary: Bamboo Not Executing Queued Builds

fields.description: Instead of having to go into each job and setup notifications, it would nice to be able to attach notification rules to a Label. This way a user does not have to hunt through all of a teams jobs to update/change/add notification and it is also easier to add a new job to a teams radar by simply labeling that job.
fields.summary: Add the Ability to Setup Notifications Based on Lables

fields.description:
h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Integrate Bamboo with Bitbucket and Jira.
# Create a plan in Bamboo.
# Run the plan manually from Bamboo.
# Create a release in Jira and chose to run a build.
# Open the plan summary screen.
# The recent history is populated with 2 entries (one corresponding to the manual run and one to the Jira release)
# Create an export of the Bamboo data
# Install a new version of Bamboo and start it. Chose custom install and import the exported data created above.
# Finish the install and login.
# Access the plan.
# In the plan summary the entryes corresponding to the Jira releases have the reason column 'Unknown'.

h3. Expected Results
The plan summary history should be the same as the one before the export.

h3. Actual Results
The plan summary history contains 'Unknown' values in the reason column.

h3.Workaround
There is no workaround
fields.summary: Reason 'Unknown' in Plan summary history after import

fields.description: Currently, you're forced to link a repository to the new build plan by selecting "previously linked repository" or "link new repository" radio buttons.  This presumes that the new build plan will be used with a source repository.  There should be a third choice which allows creation of the build plan without associating it with a repository.

fields.description: The quiet period on linked repository works on any checkout - manual, polled or remote. But I wand to intimidate build on manual and wait in case of remote trigger
fields.summary: Add quiet period option to remote trigger

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

The Bamboo Cloud instances have stock AMI IDs that are updated on Bamboo releases to new AMI IDs. This allows updates to be delivered to stock images.

However, this causes problems sometimes, when the new AMI IDs don't have all the same resources/capabilities of the previous images. If builds rely on these capabilities, builds may fail.

These updates also happen on custom defined images in Bamboo, if they use the same AMI IDs that are updated.

An example of changed capability is the Java version, which may change. If the user needs the previous version, this can be a problem.

h3. Suggested Solution
Add an option to image definitions in Bamboo Cloud that prevent the image from being changed on updates.
fields.summary: Allow definitions of stock images to not be upgraded

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Some Bamboo documentations say that instances are updated. For example, we can see it [here|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/stock-images-289277463.html]:
{quote}
There is a new default image (with its own AMI ID) for each new version of Bamboo. However, older default images will still be available for use.
{quote}

And [here|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamkb/list-of-atlassian-ami-ids-744721326.html]:
{quote}
Atlassian's AMIs (and hence, their IDs) may change with each release of Bamboo, including both major and minor releases. If you want to find out the AMI IDs for a version of Bamboo, this is the correct place.
{quote}

Also we can see changes in 'What's new in Cloud' [here|https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/what-s-new-686863216.html#What'sNew-bamboo]:
{quote}
Ubuntu stock images upgrade to version 5.10 Wily Werewolf
{quote}

However, it is not clear what stock images will be modified exactly. More precisely, the following information is missing or not clear:
* Will this affect 'custom definitions' using Stock AMI IDs ? 
** Not custom images, but image definitions created in Bamboo by the user using a Stock AMI
* Will 'very old' stock images be updated? That is, will this only update AMI IDs added in the last previous update, or even older stock images are updated?
** For example, if the user adds an old AMI ID that has already been replaced/updated in Bamboo.
* Are any AMI IDs that were not updated still supported by Atlassian (or is it treated as a custom image)?
** For example, if the user manually changes the AMI ID to use the an old one that should've been updated.

h3. Suggested Solution
Clarify in the documentation the three topics above.
fields.summary: Clarify update of old elastic stock images in Bamboo Cloud

fields.description:
This morning, we had a bunch of Build plans stacked up because they were waiting for an elastic instance to spawn (we only have one type).  Manually starting some elastic instances caused the plans to start executing.

I also noticed last night that we had 3 elastic instances that had been running for a week, even though the idle timeout was set to 10 minutes.  I terminated those manually and those may have been working OK for that whole time, which is why we didn't notice a problem earlier.
fields.summary: Elastic instances not spawning automatically

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
The remote agent authentication tab does not display show any association between the authentication entry, agent UUID and the _real_ agent that this corresponds to. This make managing the authentication entries difficult with higher agent counts.

h3. Suggested Solution
Implement a link between Agent UUID and Agent ID. The Agent Authentication tab could display:
* Existing agents (hostname) that the authentication entry applies to. If the authentication entry does not link to an existing agent, the UI should say as much.
* For hosts with multiple agents, it'd be beneficial to also display the agent home directory location in the agent summary screen.
* The agent summary should display linked UUIDs / approval. Being able to revoke authentication from this UI would also be beneficial.
* BAM-18647: deletion of an agent should revoke the access as well (cleaning agent_authentication table for that agent only).
 
h3. Workaround  1
The only way to map a Bamboo remote agent back to its UUID / Agent Authentication is via the filesystem on the remote agent. The details are stored in the *<bamboo-agent-home>/bamboo-agent.cfg.xml*. Example below:
{code}
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="no"?>
<configuration>
<buildWorkingDirectory>/root/bamboo-agent-home/xml-data/build-dir</buildWorkingDirectory>
<agentUuid>ff674641-a868-43ef-9e92-c2e67fbef71b</agentUuid>
<agentDefinition>
<id>70189058</id>
<name>localhost</name>
<description>Remote agent on host localhost</description>
</agentDefinition>
</configuration>
{code}

Using the UUID and *name* of the agent, you can then track this back to the authentication entry. 

Furthermore you use the information from the *bamboo-agent.cfg.xml* to query the following database tables like in the below example (there is no link between agent ID and UUID in the database though):
{code}
// Using agentUuid from bamboo-agent.cfg.xml
SELECT * FROM AGENT_AUTHENTICATION WHERE UUID = 'ff674641-a868-43ef-9e92-c2e67fbef71b';

// Using id from bamboo-agent.cfg.xml
SELECT * FROM QUEUE WHERE QUEUE_ID = 70189058;
{code}

h3. Workaround 2
Enable TRACE log level for class {{com.atlassian.bamboo.buildqueue.manager.RemoteAgentManagerImpl}} and in logs it will print agent id and UUID from heartbeat agent messages. Then follow steps from Workaround 1 to map agent id to agent name
fields.summary: Map Agent UUID (authentication entry) to the actual Remote Agent in the Bamboo UI

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When working with the Artifact Download task, a plan cannot be selected from the *Source plan* dropdown if the plan was not selected from the initial list but instead found via type-ahead in the field. This only affects Chrome.

h3. Environment
* Bamboo 5.10.3
* Chrome 49.0.2623.112 (Firefox is *not* affected)

h3. Steps to Reproduce

# Log into a Bamboo instance that has many plans (more than 25)
# Edit a plan and select a job to edit
# Click *Add task*
# Click *Artifact download*
# Expand the *Source plan* dropdown, but do not select an entry from the list ("the initial list")
# Click in the field and start typing the name of plan that is *not* displayed in the initial

h3. Expected Results

The resulting plan in the list is clickable and clicking it populates the *Source plan* field with it.

h3. Actual Results

# The plan is not clickable.
# Clicking outside the field and subsequently clicking *Save* returns error *Specified plan key is not a valid key* and now populates the *Source plan* field. A subsequent *Save* works without errors.

h3.Workaround

If available, use Firefox. Alternatively rather than clicking the plan, click outside the field, click *Save* (an error will now occur, but the *Source plan* field will now be populated with the plan you wanted to select) and click *Save* again.
fields.summary: Plan cannot be selected in Artifact Download task if the plan was found through type-ahead instead of the initial list of plans

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Customers with several AWS accounts sometimes need their Bamboo Agents to be able to to talk to resources in another AWS account. Those agents are on a different VPC with no internal connection thus requiring external connection which needs to be allowed at security group. There is currently no way for Bamboo to fix public IP address so that inbound rules needs to accept access from anywhere in the world.

h3. Suggested Solution

Allow EC2 agents to be able to set a fixed public IP address so that the inbound rules can be set to specifically that IP and not the entire internet.
 
h3. Workaround

None.
fields.summary: All Bamboo EC2 Agents to set a fixed public IP address

fields.description:

I renamed the existing temp directory and created a new one and the folder is continuously seeing 40+ files per second being created.  We also are not able to run build plans now, etting errors like this:

fields.description:
h3. Summary
The API call Bamboo makes to Bitbucket Cloud after build completion to update the build status may occasionally fail for various reasons. It appears Bamboo makes no attempt to retry or reconcile these calls should they fail. Consequently, build status information in Bitbucket Cloud will be left incorrect or incomplete should these calls fail.
\\
\\
h3. Steps to Reproduce
Issue is intermittent in most cases but having two build plans that trigger on the same commit appears to be a reliable way to reproduce the behavior.
# Configure Bamboo to use a Bitbucket Cloud repository
# Create two build plans that build from that same repository\branch
# Configure plan triggers to execute plans on commit
# Enable debug logging for the following packages in Bamboo
{{com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.bitbucket.api.BitbucketApiException}}
{{com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.bitbucket.api.BitbucketApiService}}
# Make a commit in the Bitbucket Cloud repository in order to trigger the build plans

\\
h3. Expected Results
Bamboo updates the build status on completion and the correct status for all builds executed is reflected in Bitbucket Cloud.
\\
\\
h3. Actual Results
If the post build status update fails, build status is either not present or incomplete in Bitbucket Cloud and will remain as such.

Logs will contain varying levels of error detail depending on how the call failed. Below message is most common.
{noformat}
2016-04-19 02:26:20,549 INFO [AtlassianEvent::0-BAM::EVENTS:pool-2-thread-3] [BitbucketBuildStatusUpdater] Unable to sent build status update to Bitb
ucket
{noformat}

In addition, Bitbucket Cloud may return an HTTP error code response that will cause the call to fail.

fields.description:
h2. Summary

As pointed out by the title itself, a cloned deployment project currently still takes the snapshot (thus together with the previous project configurations) of the previous deployment project configurations into consideration. 

If you try to run this cloned deployment project, the build will fail because it is using the definitions of the previous deployment project. To fix this, you need to make a new release, only then the cloned deployment project will use the current project settings.

Ideally, the cloned project should immediately take the latest settings instead of having to create a new release first.
fields.summary: Cloned deployment project should take value from the latest configuration instead of the snapshot of the previous project

fields.description: While transitioning between environments, it would be good to disable one so that no one can accidentally deploy on that environment until the transition is complete after which we then want to delete the environment. We dont want to delete it until it is transitioned OR we may choose to update it to use the new environment once completed. But need it disabled until then.

fields.description:
Hi,

We stumbled upon a problem in bamboo where it cannot checkout a git submodule 
 
* developer makes changes in a locally cloned submodule
* she then moves submodule HEAD in superproject without pushing her local changes in submodule itself
* Bamboo starts building project plan and because of the above fails with "fatal: reference is not a tree" error.
* Bamboo then deletes all the files in problematic submodule (confirmed by git status)
* Subsequent builds fail because files are not there anymore and

fields.description:
Bamboo Xcode plugin uses `xcrun PackageApplication` command to create .ipa file.
Due to bug in `PackageApplication` script, in case of project with Swift sources, .ipa file doesn't include `SwiftSupport` folder that required by AppStore. 

To fix this problem Xcode plugin has to add required files after creating .ipa archive. 

There is an example how [shenzhen|https://github.com/nomad/shenzhen] tool does required steps:

 
{code:none}
   # Determine whether this is a Swift project and, eventually, the list of libraries to copy from
    # Xcode's toolchain directory since there's no "xcodebuild" target to do just that (it is done
    # post-build when exporting an archived build from the "Organizer").
    @ipa_swift_frameworks = Dir["#{@app_path}/Frameworks/libswift*"]

    if not @ipa_swift_frameworks.empty?
      Dir.mktmpdir do |tmpdir|
        # Copy all necessary Swift libraries to a temporary "SwiftSupport" directory so that we can
        # easily add it to the .ipa later.
        swift_support = File.join(tmpdir, "SwiftSupport")

        Dir.mkdir(swift_support)

        @ipa_swift_frameworks.each do |path|
          framework = File.basename(path)

          FileUtils.copy_file("#{xcode}/Toolchains/XcodeDefault.xctoolchain/usr/lib/swift/#{@sdk}/#{framework}", File.join(swift_support, framework))
        end

        # Add "SwiftSupport" to the .ipa archive
        Dir.chdir(tmpdir) do
          abort unless system %{zip --recurse-paths "#{@ipa_path}" "SwiftSupport" #{'> /dev/null' unless $verbose}}
        end
      end
    end
{code}
fields.summary: Bamboo Xcode plugin produces .ipa file incompatible with AppStore

fields.description:
Hello !

We have a long-running job that generate data, and it runs nightly. However, sometimes we need to stop it manually to allow other tasks to run. The tool of this job is a python script that can handle ctrl+c events, and it can properly set the working data in a 'paused' state, so a subsequent run of this job will resume the work instead of restarting from scratch. Sadly, stopping a build appears to just kill the processes.

Is it possible to implement the following feature: select what do when cancelling a task:

 - send Ctrl+C (or SIGINT on linux)
 - send SIGTERM (I don't know the equivalent on Windows, maybe WM_QUIT?)
 - just kill it (like a kill -9)

Also a documentation page would be very nice (maybe I missed it ?).

Thank you !
fields.summary: Feature request: allow graceful build termination

fields.description:
h4. Problem Definition
Although Bamboo is case sensitive regarding groups it only allows users to create groups in lower-case and without spaces. This sometimes creates a trap for users switching from internal to external user directories, since they are not able to create groups in Bamboo to match the groups from the external directory (if they have spaces or upper-case characters) to give them the correct permissions before actually switching to the new directory.
     
h4. Suggested Solution
Allow Bamboo to handle groups creation with upper-case, lower-case characters and spaces.
 
h4. Workaround
Add a group to the external directory matching a group with admin permissions in Bamboo. After that you are able to add the groups from the external directory to the correct permissions (even when they have spaces or upper-case characters).
fields.summary: Allow Bamboo to create groups with upper-case charactes and spaces

fields.description:
Appears to be an issue with when repo checkout happens for a build, Bamboo is not reading the correct value of a variable out of the database, it is using an older, cached version of that variable. For ex:

Database value: my.repo.branch = release/2016.7
Plan configuration variable page: my.repo.branch =  release/2016.7
Build log: {noformat}Substituting variable: ${my.repo.branch} with release/2016.6{noformat}

The build log shows Bamboo still trying to checkout the old value of that variable. Restarting Bamboo appears to reload all variables from the database and the builds kick off again fine, using the correct release/2016.7 variable.

This seems to have been introduced with 5.10, had no problems with the variable substitution not reading the correct value from the database in 5.9
fields.summary: Plan variables not being substituted correctly into build

fields.description:
h3. Summary

The SCP Task in Bamboo doesn't copy the following folders and files to the remote path:

{noformat}
As of Ant 1.8.1 they are:
     **/*~
     **/#*#
     **/.#*
     **/%*%
     **/._*
     **/CVS
     **/CVS/**
     **/.cvsignore
     **/SCCS
     **/SCCS/**
     **/vssver.scc
     **/.svn
     **/.svn/**
     **/.DS_Store

Ant 1.8.2 adds the following default excludes:

     **/.git
     **/.git/**
     **/.gitattributes
     **/.gitignore
     **/.gitmodules
     **/.hg
     **/.hg/**
     **/.hgignore
     **/.hgsub
     **/.hgsubstate
     **/.hgtags
     **/.bzr
     **/.bzr/**
{noformat}

h3. Steps to Reproduce

# Create a Plan and configure the Plan to checkout code from a VCS repository.
# Create two tasks inside the Plan:
#* a) Source Code Checkout
#* b) SCP Task
# Configure the SCP Task to copy all the files from your build working directory over to another directory.
# Select the _Use Ant patterns to select files_ option.

h3. Expected Results

The build will checkout code from your VCS repository to the build working directory and the SCP Task will copy *all* the files over to the new location specified in the task.

h3. Actual Results

The SCP Task doesn't copy all files over. This is happening because there are a set of definitions that are excluded by default from all directory-based tasks when using the *Ant* patterns.

h3. Possible Solution

It is possible to disable the default excludes with the {{defaultexcludes="no"}} attribute according to the [Ant documentation|http://ant.apache.org/manual/dirtasks.html].

h3.Workaround

Use a _Script_ Task in Bamboo to manually copy the files and folders over to the remote path.
fields.summary: SCP Task to disable Ant default excludes

fields.description:
Is there any reason to choose one of the 4 supported DBs over another from bamboo perspective? (oracle, mySQL, SQL, PostgresSQL).

what are the performance expectations of bamboo with each DB system? To give you an idea of the size of data and activity, we have an organization with over 100 repositories and 200 developers across 20 teams. We plan to have parallel plans in the system and we might be running either the 25 remote agent or 100 remote agent level with many different test platforms attached and deployment processes too.

we're also integrating with the full atlassian suite (JIRA, bitbucket, confluence, hipchat)

The [best practices section|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/bamboo-best-practice-system-requirements-388401170.html] is vague.

We don't have an installation so there is nothing to be measured locally. It is shocking that there is no information like this from atlassian.

It is interesting that every other question I've asked has been answered quickly. This one is a run around. Searching forums you never know what you're going to get and you can't compare results because of system variances from person to person.

It is also surprising that there are no hardware tiers above 16 core, and the low amount of ram. I wonder what happens when you higher. I didn't see any hardware recommendations for remote agents either

Very disappointed
fields.summary: Bamboo Performances Expectation

fields.summary: Longer plan descriptions

fields.description:
h3. Summary
* Crowd has an option send *lowercase* username/group information to Bamboo
** this option prevents permissions granted to users and groups in Bamboo from validating

h3. Steps to reproduce
h4. 1. Crowd
# add an Bamboo Application in *Crowd*
# add an UPPERCASE group (_e.g.: BAMBOO-CROWD_)
# add user to the group above
{code:sql}
select * from cwd_user where user_name = "crowd.user"
{code}

h4. 2. Bamboo
# go to *Bamboo* and add Crowd under "{{Bamboo administration >> Overview >> Security >> User repositories}}"
# go to "{{Bamboo administration >> Overview >> Security >> Users}}"
||Username||Email||Full name||Groups||
|admin|admin@crowd.webserver|Administrator Crowd|bamboo-admin
crowd-administrators|
|{color:red}CROWD.USER{color}|CROWD.USER@crowd.webserver|CROWD.USER Crowd|{color:red}BAMBOO-CROWD{color}|

h4. 3. Crowd
# go to *Crowd* under "{{Application >> Bamboo >> Options}}" tab
# select "{{Lower case output}}"
||Lower case output|Convert all users and groups to lower case when passing the data to the application. This can be used to achieve case insensitivity for applications when the underlying directories contain mixed-cased data.|

h4. 4. Bamboo
# go to *Bamboo* and add Crowd under "{{Bamboo administration >> Overview >> Security >> User repositories}}" and hit *Synchronise now*
# go to "{{Bamboo administration >> Overview >> Security >> Users}}"
||Username||Email||Full name||Groups||
|admin|admin@crowd.webserver|Administrator Crowd|bamboo-admin
crowd-administrators|
|{color:red}crowd.user{color}|CROWD.USER@crowd.webserver|CROWD.USER Crowd|{color:red}bamboo-crowd{color}|
(!) Please, notice username and group are now being displayed as *lowercase*.
# go to Project / Plan under "{{Plan configuration >> Permissions}}" tab
# add a Group permission
||Groups||
||BAMBOO-CROWD|\[x\] View|[ ] Edit|\[x\] Build|[ ] Clone|[ ] Admin]
# Log in to Bamboo using CROWD.USER user

h3. Expected Result
* Bamboo should update Group name by reflecting the change within Global and Plan permissions

h3. Actual Result
* group does not have Build permissions to Project / Plan

h3. Investigation done
* permissions are granted based on Username and Group and *not* based on IDs
* usernames from External Directory are added to the Bamboo's database only when user authenticates against Bamboo. Rest calls against Crowd are made from Bamboo to gather information about user/group
* Bamboo allows Group permission to be set up as _UPPERCASE_ *or* _lowercase_

h3. Workaround
# disable "{{Lower case output}}" under "{{Application >> Bamboo >> Options}}" tab and re-sync users/groups in Bamboo;
# *OR* add user(s) / group(s) permission as they are being displayed in Bamboo (_in *lowercase* based on the above_)
||Groups||
||bamboo-crowd|\[x\] View|[ ] Edit|\[x\] Build|[ ] Clone|[ ] Admin]
# *OR* update Bamboo's database:
{panel:bgColor=#FEEFB3}
(!)   Before running any UPDATE statement, please backup your database.
{panel}
## stop Bamboo
## extract from Bamboo's database all groups from external directory (e.g.: Crowd/Jira/LDAP)
{code:sql}
select SID
  from ACL_ENTRY
 where SID not in (select groupname from groups)
   and TYPE = 'GROUP_PRINCIPAL'
 order by SID;
{code}
||SID||
|BAMBOO-CROWD|
|crowd-administrators|
## update groups to lowercase
{code:sql}
update ACL_ENTRY
   set SID = 'bamboo-crowd',
 where SID = 'BAMBOO-CROWD'
   and TYPE = 'GROUP_PRINCIPAL';
{code}
## start Bamboo
fields.summary: Group permission is not preserved when changing case in External Directory

fields.description:
In Bamboo (hosted), when managing Build Plans, it's possible to filter and expand/collapse plans inside of projects.  It also appears to automatically sort Plans alphabetically.

However, in Deploy, there's no option to do any of this. This is an issue for us as we're managing a large number of servers for several of our projects, and the list is hard to manage.

Is this something that can be added to help ease our administration of Bamboo?
fields.summary: Add sorting, filtering, and expand/collapse to Bamboo Deployments

fields.description:
I was pretty surprised when I needed to create a licensed account in BitbucketCloud to enable access from Bamboo when there are key-based authentication and OAuth methods available that other services use for integration.

On my BitBucket Team, I should be able to create a read-only ssh key and give that to Bamboo for integration.
fields.summary: Bitbucket Cloud Integration

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Creating or saving a Bitbucket Server repository in Bamboo server will have the following error in the UI:
{noformat}
Could not check if existing access key is valid: null
{noformat}

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Disable the option "SSH access keys enabled" at {{Bitbucket Server Administration >> Settings >> Server Settings}}
# Login to Bamboo server with a user that have Admin permission to the Bitbucket Server repository
# Create a Bitbucket Server repository in Bamboo server Linked repositories

h3. Expected Results
The repository will be created successfully by adding the SSH key into User account

h3. Actual Results
The below exception is thrown in UI:
{noformat}
Could not check if existing access key is valid: null
{noformat}
 
h3. Notes
No error in Bamboo or Bitbucket Server logs
Enabling debug logging in Bitbucket Server will have the following stack trace:
{noformat}
2016-04-07 13:14:33,669 DEBUG [http-nio-7990-exec-30] admin @1P5W2PDx794x67346x0 172.20.20.37 "POST /rest/keys/1.0/projects/PROJECTNAME/repos/REPONAME/ssh HTTP/1.1" c.a.s.i.r.e.ServiceExceptionMapper Mapping ServiceException to REST response 409
com.atlassian.bitbucket.ssh.SshKeyAccessDisabledException: Support for SSH access keys has been disabled. Please contact an administrator
	at com.atlassian.bitbucket.internal.key.ssh.DefaultSshAccessKeyService.set(DefaultSshAccessKeyService.java:311) ~[bitbucket-ssh-4.5.1.jar:na]
	at com.atlassian.bitbucket.internal.key.ssh.rest.SshAccessKeyResource.addForRepository(SshAccessKeyResource.java:191) ~[bitbucket-ssh-4.5.1.jar:na]
	at com.atlassian.applinks.core.rest.context.ContextFilter.doFilter(ContextFilter.java:26) [applinks-plugin-5.0.5_1459814966000.jar:na]
	at com.atlassian.applinks.core.rest.context.ContextFilter.doFilter(ContextFilter.java:26) [applinks-plugin-5.0.5_1459814966000.jar:na]
	at com.atlassian.applinks.core.rest.context.ContextFilter.doFilter(ContextFilter.java:26) [applinks-plugin-5.0.5_1459814966000.jar:na]
	at com.atlassian.applinks.core.rest.context.ContextFilter.doFilter(ContextFilter.java:26) [applinks-plugin-5.0.5_1459814966000.jar:na]
	at com.atlassian.applinks.core.rest.context.ContextFilter.doFilter(ContextFilter.java:26) [applinks-plugin-5.0.5_1459814966000.jar:na]
	at com.atlassian.plugin.connect.plugin.auth.scope.ApiScopingFilter.doFilter(ApiScopingFilter.java:89) [atlassian-connect-plugin-1.1.70-bitbucket-01.jar:na]
{noformat}

h3.Workaround
# Create a new user in Bitbucket Server that does not have Admin permission to Bitbucket Server Project or Repository
# Create the same user in Bamboo Server (this user will have Admin permission in Bamboo)
# Use the new user to create Bitbucket Server repository so that the SSH key is added into Bitbucket Server User Account instead of Bitbucket Server Repository Access Key
fields.summary: Could not create Bitbucket Server repository in Bamboo server if Bitbucket Server SSH Access Key is disabled

fields.description:
The following URI parameters inside the [Bamboo REST Resources|https://developer.atlassian.com/bamboodev/rest-apis/bamboo-rest-resources#BambooRESTResources-BuildService%E2%80%94SpecificBuildResult] documentation, under *Build Service — Specific Build Result*, seem to be incorrect:

{noformat}
?expand=results.result.artifacts — Lists the artifacts for the specified build result.
?expand=results.result.labels — Lists the labels for the specified build result.
?expand=results.result.comments — Lists the comments for the specified build result.
?expand=results.result.jiraIssues — Lists the JIRA issues for the specified build result.
{noformat}

This was tested against Bamboo 5.10.3 and none of them seem to work. The problem seems to be related to using {{results.result}} before the final parameter. If this is removed, then the REST API call works and expand the desired section. The documentation should be updated to:

{noformat}
?expand=artifacts — Lists the artifacts for the specified build result.
?expand=labels — Lists the labels for the specified build result.
?expand=comments — Lists the comments for the specified build result.
?expand=jiraIssues — Lists the JIRA issues for the specified build result.
{noformat}
fields.summary: Update Dev Documentation for Bamboo REST Resources

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Currently dedicating an agent is not captured as an event in the audit log. This makes it difficult to track down changes made to dedications.

h3. Suggested Solution
Log an event to the audit log comprising the responsible user, time, agent and any changes to plan dedications.
fields.summary: Dedicate agent not in audit log

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
    The document [Assigning responsibility for build failures|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Assigning+responsibility+for+build+failures] describes a behavior that does not correspond what we find in Bamboo feature.

    Not all the committers are added as responsible for failing build. At least the following case is an exception:
    * When there is a merge from a pull request, only the responsible for the merge is assigned as responsible for the failing build.
    This behavior seems coherent once a pull request could have lots of committers. This way only the responsible for the merge is assigned and he is able to assign the responsibility to the specific developer who broke the build.

h3. Suggested Solution
    The document [Assigning responsibility for build failures|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Assigning+responsibility+for+build+failures] should contemplate the above case.
    This is the part that should change:
    {quote}
    People are assigned as being responsible for fixing a broken build in two ways:

    * When a build fails, Bamboo automatically assigns all those who committed code to the failing build as responsible.
    * You can manually assign people as being responsible.
    {quote}

    It could be changed to:
    {quote}
    People are assigned as being responsible for fixing a broken build in two ways:
    * When a build fails, Bamboo automatically assigns as responsible:
    ** All those who committed to the plan branch's repository whose build failed
    ** Only the responsible for a merge from a pull request, not all the committers involved in that merge

    * You can manually assign people as being responsible.
    {quote}
fields.summary: Not all commiters are added as responsible for a failed build
